author: Mario Ledwith, Tom Witherow And Glen Keogh For The Daily Mail
title: Top consultants used code words to arrange hospital sex
text:
A 'sex ring' involving two male NHS consultants and other staff orchestrated trysts in hospital rooms while they were supposed to be caring for patients, it has been alleged.
The health workers exchanged hundreds of emails in which they used code words to arrange sexual liaisons at one of the country's top hospitals.
The discovery of the sordid activity – which often took place yards from patients – has led to claims of a cover-up after the hospital refused to sack the two highly-paid consultants after a disciplinary hearing lasting just 20 minutes.
Emails discovered during an investigation found that the pair, who are both married and have children, were at the centre of the group, which included three female secretarial and clerical members of staff.
Valerie Leon and Jim Dale (pictured together) starred in the 1969 film Carry On Again Doctor
A source said sexual partners were 'shared' between the two consultants at the Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle. Their code words are said to have included 'going for a cappuccino' to mean intercourse, and obscure references to 'spreading Marmite'.
Concerns have also been raised that the group took photographs of their activity.
The consultants, who have 50 years' medical experience between them, allegedly met one of the women – called 'the Madam' – when they worked at another hospital.
Sources fear the individuals carried out the activities for more than a year. One said: 'It [the behaviour] was horrendous and it would make your hair curl. You don't do things like that in a clinic, when there are patients outside. Things are very unpleasant at the minute, all down to this.'
Furious colleagues have accused Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust of a cover-up after it emerged that the consultants were not sacked.
The existence of the group's activity was discovered last year after a whistleblower raised concerns. An investigation unearthed the trove of emails, which contained details about the trysts taking place in offices, clinical rooms and outside the hospital's premises.
The pair were suspended, but a disciplinary panel led by trust chairman Kingsley Smith and non-executive director Dr Bryan Dobson took 20 minutes to give them a formal warning. The decision, which allowed the pair to return to work with a recommendation that they receive counselling, was described as 'laughable' by one colleague at the trust. Another said it amounted to a 'slap on the wrist'.
The unnamed 'Madam' is understood to have left the trust before moving abroad, while the other two mystery women also left their roles.
A trust employee said: 'If it had been anybody lower down, they would have been sacked immediately and they were just suspended and not made to resign.' They added: 'It's only because they are doctors and have a reputation and the authorities think it is too much for them to give up.'
Another worker said: 'The decision was against everybody's advice. They [the consultants] thought they were untouchable. If that had been a porter or a domestic, their feet wouldn't have touched the ground.'
A source said sexual partners were 'shared' between the two consultants at the Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle (pictured)
The trust declined to hand over documents after four Freedom of Information requests were lodged, citing data protection rules.
Despite being allowed to return to work, both consultants, who earned approximately £90,000, later resigned.
They came under pressure after a group of colleagues sent a letter to the General Medical Council saying they could no longer work with the pair. Although an official referral was also sent to the regulator by the trust, the GMC decided not to investigate. A source accused the GMC, which said the trysts were an isolated occurrence, of 'washing their hands' of the incident.
A spokesman for the trust said: 'Our disciplinary procedures follow national guidelines ... Panels consider all of the evidence carefully and are independent.
'In addition the GMC also considers matters of the medical profession and has its own independent review process.'
Mr Smith and Dr Dobson said they could not discuss the case for confidentiality reasons. The Care Quality Commission refused to comment.
